item.title: Abridged Research Statement
item.description: I am interested in how actions of political elites – including not only elected leaders but a broad set of influencers who rely on either established or social media – affect voters’s lives and decisions. Among the political choices I am interested are: conveyance of economic data and events, competition for elected office, and attempts to politicize new issues. As political discourse permeates into citizen’s screens and pockets, many observers worry that permanent campaigning, populist rhetoric, and echo chambers are eroding democracy.

item.title: Contact
item.description: Recent/upcoming opportunities to meet: Provo (July 2018) Boston (Late August - Early Sept. 2018) Abu Dhabi (January 2019) Chicago (April 2019) New York (most of the year) I generally welcome face-to-face conversations with other social scientists, journalists, and other people. item.title: Introduction
item.description: I am a Ph.D. candidate in the Department of Politics at NYU and Research Associate at the Social Media and Political Participation Lab. In my work I study aspects of American politics (voting, public opinion, media use). A recent project exploits survey data augmented with respondents’ social media data to analyze voters’ expectations prior to the 2016 election. Another project uses text data to shed light on political mobilization of non-traditional campaign surrogates.
